tweets.text:
Topic assigned per @vgr

I dropped out of law school to join the Army, became an airborne scout, deployed to Afghanistan, got out and finished law school, transitioned to tech.

Upper bound 100? Probably don't have that many tho lol https://t.co/FkicyKOdjn

1. This is kind of a trick question. I'm a very... unmilitary person, but I'll always be a veteran. It colors how others perceive me, opens some doors, affects my inner life, creates a bond with other vets.

In this sense there is no transition from the military

2. Many people outright never transition in any meaningful way. They become government contractors or employees or consultants, GS-types with their own parallel ranking system.

Same career safety, occasional exposure to physical risk, a little more bureaucratic

3. Late Halloween night in Prague, in a James Dean-themed bar, I met a heavily tattooed ex-Marine. He'd been drinking his way across Europe for weeks, shipped back to Afghanistan in a few days.

Normal combat-arms like me don't get merc jobs, he was one tough dude. Hella PTSD.

4. Uber driver offered me a free ride after finding we're both vets.

He married a lovely Austin girl, says he's always unstressed. No one's shooting at him. Someone cares for him.

Difficult to communicate certain skills to civilians, eg "ability to manage murderous co-workers."

5. Brother of mine transitioned Army to Coast Guard.

Formal military, preserves all time in service and retirement benefits, but also a 9-to-5 job on American soil.

He reminisces about bizarro Army-world with other Army vets - also set apart from normal Coasties. Same, not-same

6. Dinner convo tonight: helo pilot figuring out how to transition to airline plane pilot 

She could work for a regional airline, or pay/train to accumulate enough hours for a major airline

Airlines desperate for pilots as older cohort ages out

Concrete career/skill transfer

7. A more civilian example: after 30 years in Navy, my dad worked for consulting firm that contracted for various government projects.

He had general executive skills, knowledge of gov budgeting processes, certain contract bids give preferential treatment to veterans and others

8. Right after Army exit, I rode my motorcycle for six months from Alaska to Argentina, with a brother (my parents: "you'll die! Take your brother!")

You know, I was *grumpy*. Had some detoxing to do.

Let my beard grow. Got lost sneaking into Bolivia, hiked Macchu Picchu, etc.

9. Friend who served mandatory stint in Singaporean army, ages 17-19, said he just turned his brain off, did whatever he was told, tried not to think. 

But it's increased his overall gratefulness - he's not there any more!

One of our very best software engineers now.

10. Friend who runs a coding bootcamp for soon-to-exit soldiers asked them the innocuous question: so why'd you join the Army?

They started crying. Many had escaped great hardship - but then were disillusioned by the Army treating them like idiots with only menial tasks to do.

11. When active duty, I traveled in civilian clothing, never boarded first. I lie low on Veterans' Day etc.

otoh I used the hell out of my GI Bill, VA loan, free access to Austin city parks, etc.

Don't have that much pride.
